channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Affirms Stance That Rights Treaty Doesn’t Apply Abroad
item.description: In making its declaration, the Obama administration rejected an interpretation by the United Nations and a former top State Department lawyer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Russia Massing Military Forces Near Border With Ukraine
item.description: Russia acknowledged significant operations in several regions abutting Ukraine, even as Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany assailed the Kremlin’s actions.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ALISON SMALE

item.title: Lens Blog: An Uncertain Quiet for Crimean Tatars
item.description: More than 20 years after her family returned from decades of exile to their Crimean roots, Emine Ziyatdinova wonders if the upheaval in Crimea will again force Tatars from their homeland.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Dinner at Abdul' Seit-Ametov house. Mr. Seit-Ametov is Crimean Tatar artist working with traditional ceramics and ornaments.

item.title: World Briefing : Chinese Police Detain Activist Who Runs Website
item.description: Huang Qi, a well-known human-rights advocate and blogger, was taken from his home by police officers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 13
item.description: An irrigation canal embankment on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar, Orissa.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Search for Missing Jet Shifts to Indian Ocean Amid Confusion Over Radar
item.description: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Muslims prayed for passengers of the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 plane on Thursday at the departure hall of the Kuala Lumpur International Airport.

item.title: Ban on Doctors’ Group Imperils Myanmar’s Poor
item.description: The government halted the work of Doctors Without Borders after some officials accused the group of favoring a Muslim minority over Buddhists.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother with her newborn baby in the segregated northern area of Sittwe in Rakhine State.

item.title: In Ukraine, Many See Polish Economy as a Blueprint
item.description: Ukrainian business executives say Western aid may prove a Band-Aid unless Kiev faces its structural challenges and sheds its communist past, like Poland did decades ago.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Yurko Dyachyshyn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lviv, only an hour’s drive east of the Polish border, has learned to adjust to changing rule, from the Austro-Hungarian Empire to the Nazis to the Soviets.

item.title: India Ink: High Court Upholds Death Penalty in Delhi Gang Rape Case
item.description: The judges said a strong message needed to be sent to “the perpetrators of grotesque and ghastly crimes against women.”
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Protesters outside a court in New Delhi on Thursday demanding the death sentence for all those accused in the December 2012 gang rape of a medical student, including a defendant who was a juvenile at the time.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Buddhist Volunteers Aiding Anxious Families in Beijing
item.description: As relatives in Beijing await news from the missing Malaysian Airlines jetliner, volunteers from the Tzu Chi Foundation, a Buddhist charitable organization headquartered in Taiwan, have been busy offering counseling and other assistance.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer with the Tzu Chi Foundation, center, spoke with relatives of passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 at the Metropark Lido Hotel in Beijing.

item.title: Gaza-Israel Escalation Threatens Cease-Fire
item.description: Rocket fire into Israel continued for a second day, jeopardizing the American-led peace talks and a truce that has held for 16 months.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers stand near the Iron Dome, Israel’s unique anti-rocket interceptor system, in Ashkelon on Thursday.

item.title: Ukrainian Billionaire Arrested in Austria
item.description: Dmitry V. Firtash, an ally of the ousted Ukraine leader Viktor F. Yanukovych, is suspected of bribery. American law enforcement officials had been tracking him.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Ukrainian billionaire Dmitry V. Firtash in Kiev in 2010.

item.title: India Ink: India Welcomes Dismissal of Visa Fraud Case Against Diplomat
item.description: The United States District Court in New York dismissed a case against Devyani Khobragade after determining that she had diplomatic immunity at the time of her federal indictment.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, after her return to New Delhi on Jan. 10. Ms. Khobragade was arrested in New York last year on charges of lying to the United States government to obtain a visa for her housekeeper, who prosecutors said had been paid far less than New York State’s minimum wage.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For Foreign Journalists in Beijing, It’s All About Asking the Right Question
item.description: A news conference with the Chinese prime minister and foreign journalists each year is broadcast worldwide, but is actually staged, with the complicity of many of the largest news organizations in Western journalism.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China took questions that had been pre-approved at a news conference at the close of the National People's Congress on Thursday.

item.title: Plane’s Locating Device Went Silent Before Disappearance
item.description: One mystery surrounding the lost Malaysian jet concerns the plane’s transponder, which apparently stopped functioning about 40 minutes into the flight.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Military Repatriates Algerian Detainee From Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The transfer is the first in nearly three months, and it reduces the inmate population to 154, part of an ongoing effort to close the facility.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Why Do Men Dominate Chinese Politics? Because They’re ‘Just Too Superb’
item.description: The National People’s Congress has slightly more women than in previous sessions, but women still remain a rarity at the top levels of Chinese politics. This gender gap might be due to a “quality” issue, some female delegates said.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Delegates took part in the closing of the National People's Congress on Thursday. Women make up 23.4 percent of the rubber-stamp legislature, and only 4.9 percent of the ruling Communist Party's Central Committee.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Offering a German Lesson for Asia’s History Wars
item.description: Nearly 70 years after the end of World War II, China and Japan are still verbally and symbolically battling over wartime traumas that have long been resolved in Europe.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Ukraine, Revisiting Ghosts of Crises Past
item.description: As the showdown in Ukraine headed toward a referendum in Crimea, themes from the past intruded into the debate: irredentism and appeasement.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Germany Urges Russia to Help Solve Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that failure to help find a negotiated solution would severely damage Russia politically and economically.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel spoke at the German Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Across Turkey, New Unrest as Teenage Boy Is Buried
item.description: More than 100,000 mourners in Istanbul attended a funeral procession for a 15-year-old felled by a police tear-gas canister, and new unrest erupted.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Riot police used tear gas to disperse protesters on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: When Voting in India, What’s in a Name?
item.description: The author fondly recalls his first campaign experience in Mumbai, which included electoral rolls full of misspellings and typewritten “love letters” to a candidate.
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA

item.title: Self-Described Champion of India’s Poor Faces Court Scrutiny
item.description: The jailed tycoon Subrata Roy faces accusations that many of his company’s investment vehicles are illegal and its investors fictitious.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Ink was thrown at Subrata Roy, chairman of the Sahara Group, as he arrived at India’s Supreme Court last week.

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Limits Merkel’s Rapport With Putin
item.description: With Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany failing to sway President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Ukraine, Germans are wondering whether a policy of conciliation with Russia has run its course.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Berlin in June 2012. Their countries have been trading partners, and rivals, for centuries.

item.title: Interactions of Bin Laden and Son-in-Law Detailed in an F.B.I. Document
item.description: Lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who is on trial on terrorism charges, sought permission from a judge to present the document, a full summary of his interrogation, to the jury.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:credit: Al-Jazeera, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
